segments.text_en: The most important things I know about negotiation,
segments.text_zh: 我所知道的关于谈判的最重要的事情

segments.text_en: I learned in a kayak on my honeymoon.
segments.text_zh: 我在蜜月时在皮划艇上学习。

segments.text_en: Picture this, I arrive in Hawaii and I look adoring me at my brand new husband
segments.text_zh: 想象一下，我到达夏威夷，我看起来很崇拜我的新丈夫

segments.text_en: as we get in a two person kayak together for a river tour.
segments.text_zh: as we get in a two person kayak together for a river tour.

segments.text_en: Then things go wrong, fast.
segments.text_zh: 然后事情就会出问题，速度很快。

segments.text_en: You see, in a two person kayak, the passenger in the back, usually the larger passenger,
segments.text_zh: 你看，在两人皮划艇中，后面的乘客，通常是体型较大的乘客，

segments.text_en: is supposed to drive using their paddles.
segments.text_zh: 应该使用他们的桨来驾驶。

segments.text_en: Well, I didn't like how he was driving.
segments.text_zh: 嗯，我不喜欢他开车的方式。

segments.text_en: So I decided to drive my own way.
segments.text_zh: 所以我决定自己开车。

segments.text_en: And exactly at the moment I thought I had taken over, we flipped over.
segments.text_zh: 就在我以为我已经接管了一切的那一刻，我们发生了翻天覆地的变化。

segments.text_en: Three separate times.
segments.text_zh: 分别三次。

segments.text_en: Apparently we set a record.
segments.text_zh: 显然我们创造了记录。

segments.text_en: So I get back in the kayak, now dripping wet, when our guide up ahead turns back and says,
segments.text_zh: 于是我回到了皮划艇上，浑身湿透了，这时我们前面的导游转过身来说道：

segments.text_en: okay folks, let's negotiate these things to the left because you're going to hit that beach up ahead.
segments.text_zh: 好吧，伙计们，让我们向左协商这些事情，因为您将到达前面的海滩。

segments.text_en: Negotiate the kayak.
segments.text_zh: 协商皮划艇。

segments.text_en: In that moment, I realized that although I had been teaching negotiation for a few years already,
segments.text_zh: 在那一刻，我意识到虽然我已经教授谈判几年了，

segments.text_en: I had missed something important.
segments.text_zh: 我错过了一些重要的事情。

segments.text_en: And I was not alone.
segments.text_zh: 我并不孤单。

segments.text_en: A lot of us have misconceptions about negotiation.
segments.text_zh: A lot of us have misconceptions about negotiation.

segments.text_en: We're taught that it's a battle over money, that it involves losing.
segments.text_zh: 我们被告知这是一场金钱之争，它意味着失败。

segments.text_en: So we either fear it or we avoid it altogether.
segments.text_zh: 所以我们要么害怕它，要么完全避免它。

segments.text_en: In fact, 54% of us didn't negotiate our last salary.
segments.text_zh: 事实上，我们中有 54% 的人没有就最后一份薪水进行谈判。

segments.text_en: That's from research, by the way, I'm not actually seeing into your souls.
segments.text_zh: 顺便说一句，这是来自研究的结果，我实际上并没有洞察你的灵魂。

segments.text_en: The fact is that before that guide, I had never heard anyone use the word negotiate that way before.
segments.text_zh: 事实上，在该指南之前，我从未听过有人以这种方式使用“谈判”这个词。

segments.text_en: I too had absorbed this message that it was a contest of wills, you know, like five minutes earlier,
segments.text_zh: 我也吸收了这样的信息，那就是这是一场意志的较量，你知道，就像五分钟前一样，

segments.text_en: when I don't do SIN the River.
segments.text_zh: 当我不做河边的SIN的时候。

segments.text_en: But there's another way to think about it, isn't there?
segments.text_zh: 但还有另一种思考方式，不是吗？

segments.text_en: When I negotiate my kayak toward a beach, what am I doing?
segments.text_zh: 当我划着皮艇驶向海滩时，我在做什么？

segments.text_en: I'm steering.
segments.text_zh: 我在掌舵。

segments.text_en: Today, I want to share five lessons about negotiation that just might change your life.
segments.text_zh: 今天，我想分享五个有关谈判的教训，它们可能会改变你的生活。

segments.text_en: And the first is this.
segments.text_zh: 第一个是这个。

segments.text_en: Negotiation is simply steering.
segments.text_zh: 谈判只是指挥。

segments.text_en: It is any conversation in which you are steering a relationship.
segments.text_zh: 这是您在其中引导关系的任何对话。

segments.text_en: And it's so much more than the money conversations.
segments.text_zh: 这不仅仅是金钱方面的对话。

segments.text_en: You know, just like a kayak where we want to steer consistently to get to our goal,
segments.text_zh: 你知道，就像一艘皮划艇，我们要不断地驾驶以达到我们的目标，

segments.text_en: we can be steering our relationships almost every minute of the day.
segments.text_zh: 我们几乎每时每刻都可以掌控我们的关系。

segments.text_en: You know, when I got back from that honeymoon, I looked around and I saw opportunities to negotiate everywhere.
segments.text_zh: 你知道，当我蜜月回来后，我环顾四周，发现谈判的机会无处不在。

segments.text_en: I could be getting to know my boss is better so that I understood what they prioritized most.
segments.text_zh: 我可以更好地了解我的老板，这样我就能明白他们最优先考虑的是什么。

segments.text_en: I could be calling my clients regularly and asking them what was new in their businesses.
segments.text_zh: 我可以定期打电话给我的客户，询问他们的业务有什么新变化。

segments.text_en: And I realized something powerful.
segments.text_zh: 我意识到了一些强大的东西。

segments.text_en: If we intentionally focus on the everyday steering, what happens when we do get to the money conversations?
segments.text_zh: 如果我们有意专注于日常指导，那么当我们真正讨论金钱问题时会发生什么？

segments.text_en: We are more likely to be successful, which brings me to lesson two.
segments.text_zh: 我们更有可能成功，这让我想到了第二个教训。

segments.text_en: Curious people make more money.
segments.text_zh: 好奇的人赚更多的钱。

segments.text_en: There's one negotiation technique that most of us are not using.
segments.text_zh: 我们大多数人都没有使用一种谈判技巧。

segments.text_en: So years ago, a professor set people up to negotiate as part of a study.
segments.text_zh: So years ago, a professor set people up to negotiate as part of a study.

segments.text_en: Only 7% of those people achieved the optimal outcome.
segments.text_zh: 其中只有 7% 的人取得了最佳结果。

segments.text_en: What did they do?
segments.text_zh: 他们做了什么？

segments.text_en: Well, they didn't lead with their points.
segments.text_zh: 好吧，他们没有以他们的观点领先。

segments.text_en: They asked questions first.
segments.text_zh: 他们首先提出问题。

segments.text_en: Bottom line in negotiation, you get more by asking questions than you do by arguing.
segments.text_zh: 在谈判中，最重要的是，提出问题比争论能得到更多。

segments.text_en: But not just any questions.
segments.text_zh: 但不仅仅是任何问题。

segments.text_en: That 7% they asked open questions.
segments.text_zh: 那 7% 他们提出了开放性问题。

segments.text_en: Questions that uncovered the other person's needs, concerns and goals.
segments.text_zh: 揭示对方的需求、关注点和目标的问题。

segments.text_en: And most of us aren't great at that.
segments.text_zh: 而我们大多数人都不擅长这一点。

segments.text_en: When I teach people about asking questions, I say, okay, I've just taken a trip.
segments.text_zh: 当我教人们如何提问时，我会说，好吧，我刚刚旅行过。

segments.text_en: What can you ask me to get some good information?
segments.text_zh: 您可以向我询问什么以获得一些有用的信息？

segments.text_en: Top two questions they ask?
segments.text_zh: 他们最常问的两个问题是？

segments.text_en: I bet you could guess.
segments.text_zh: 我打赌你能猜到。

segments.text_en: Number one, where did you go?
segments.text_zh: 第一，你去哪儿了？

segments.text_en: Reno.
segments.text_zh: 里诺。

segments.text_en: Did you have a good time?
segments.text_zh: 你玩得开心吗？

segments.text_en: Yeah.
segments.text_zh: 是的。

segments.text_en: Two closed questions.
segments.text_zh: 两个封闭式问题。

segments.text_en: Two one word answers.
segments.text_zh: 两个字回答。

segments.text_en: So, what's the best question?
segments.text_zh: 那么，最好的问题是什么？

segments.text_en: Well, it's a little bit of a trick because technically, the best question of all doesn't end with a question mark.
segments.text_zh: 嗯，这有点诡计，因为从技术上讲，最好的问题并不是以问号结尾。

segments.text_en: It's, tell me all about your vacation.
segments.text_zh: 是的，告诉我你假期的一切。

segments.text_en: Tell me is the biggest question you can ask and it is the most powerful first question in any negotiation at work or at home.
segments.text_zh: 告诉我是你可以问的最大问题，也是工作或家庭谈判中最有力的第一个问题。

segments.text_en: With the hiring manager, tell me how the company sees the salary range for this position.
segments.text_zh: 与招聘经理一起，告诉我公司如何看待这个职位的薪资范围。

segments.text_en: With your teenager, tell me what's making you ask for a $50 a week allowance.
segments.text_zh: 和你十几岁的孩子一起，告诉我是什么让你要求每周 50 美元的津贴。

segments.text_en: Tell me gets you the most information, but it also builds trust so it creates the best deals.
segments.text_zh: 告诉我可以为您提供最多的信息，同时也可以建立信任，从而创造出最好的交易。

segments.text_en: Lesson three.
segments.text_zh: 第三课。

segments.text_en: The negotiation starts before the negotiation starts.
segments.text_zh: 谈判在谈判开始之前就开始了。

segments.text_en: Most people don't know that every negotiation actually comes in two parts.
segments.text_zh: 大多数人不知道每次谈判实际上都分为两个部分。

segments.text_en: The second part we all know about.
segments.text_zh: 第二部分我们都知道。

segments.text_en: That's where we're sitting down with someone else.
segments.text_zh: 那就是我们和别人坐在一起的地方。

segments.text_en: But that first part, that's what I call the mirror.
segments.text_zh: 但第一部分，就是我所说的镜子。

segments.text_en: Because we have to negotiate with ourselves first before we negotiate with anyone else.
segments.text_zh: 因为在与别人谈判之前，我们必须先与自己谈判。

segments.text_en: And it's the most critical part of the negotiation too.
segments.text_zh: 这也是谈判中最关键的部分。

segments.text_en: Because if we don't get this right, the negotiation stops there.
segments.text_zh: 因为如果我们做不好这一点，谈判就会停止。

segments.text_en: We don't ask.
segments.text_zh: 我们不问。

segments.text_en: We get confused about our priorities.
segments.text_zh: 我们对自己的优先事项感到困惑。

segments.text_en: We shut ourselves down before we give anybody else the chance.
segments.text_zh: 我们在给别人机会之前就关闭了自己。

segments.text_en: If you want to master the mirror, try asking yourself, how have I handled something like this successfully before?
segments.text_zh: 如果你想掌握镜子，试着问问自己，我以前是如何成功处理过类似的事情的？

segments.text_en: Did you know that research shows if we think about a time and write it down that we achieved great results before we go into negotiate?
segments.text_zh: 您是否知道，研究表明，如果我们在开始谈判之前考虑一下并写下来，我们就会取得很好的成果？

segments.text_en: We are more likely to negotiate well.
segments.text_zh: 我们更有可能顺利谈判。

segments.text_en: Why?
segments.text_zh: 为什么？

segments.text_en: Because we remind ourselves of who we are at our most powerful.
segments.text_zh: 因为我们提醒自己，我们最强大的时候是谁。

segments.text_en: And we also gather data on strategies that are likely to work for us.
segments.text_zh: And we also gather data on strategies that are likely to work for us.

segments.text_en: I once counseled someone named Mae who was struggling to ask for a raise.
segments.text_zh: 我曾经为一位名叫梅的人提供咨询，她正在努力要求加薪。

segments.text_en: In Mae's family, they were taught that you should wait until something was offered to you.
segments.text_zh: 在梅的家里，他们被教导要等待，直到有人向你提供某样东西。

segments.text_en: So I asked Mae about the last time she successfully advocated for herself.
segments.text_zh: 所以我问梅上次成功为自己辩护是什么时候。

segments.text_en: And she told me she actually felt really confident negotiating for the job in the first place.
segments.text_zh: 她告诉我，她实际上对谈判这份工作一开始就非常有信心。

segments.text_en: She really believed in the company's mission and she felt confident she could contribute.
segments.text_zh: She really believed in the company's mission and she felt confident she could contribute.

segments.text_en: You know, as Mae wrote this down, I saw her face change and her confidence grow.
segments.text_zh: 你知道，当梅写下这段话时，我看到她的脸色发生了变化，她的信心也增强了。

segments.text_en: Mae went in and she got that raise.
segments.text_zh: 梅进去了，她得到了加薪。

segments.text_en: Lesson 4.
segments.text_zh: 第 4 课。

segments.text_en: Land the plane.
segments.text_zh: 让飞机着陆。

segments.text_en: I worked with a brilliant sales executive named Brody who sometimes would lose deals because he talked too much.
segments.text_zh: 我曾与一位名叫布罗迪（Brody）的出色销售主管共事，他有时会因为说话太多而失去交易。

segments.text_en: He'd ask a great question and then he would get scared of the silence so he would eat it up with his words.
segments.text_zh: 他会问一个很好的问题，然后他会害怕沉默，所以他会用自己的话来消化它。

segments.text_en: What do you need to get this done here today?
segments.text_zh: 今天你需要什么才能在这里完成这件事？

segments.text_en: Well, I know our price point might be a little bit higher than that of our competitors, but I think if you go ahead and look at our customer reviews,
segments.text_zh: 嗯，我知道我们的价格可能比竞争对手高一点，但我认为如果您继续查看我们的客户评论，

segments.text_en: want to know the secret to great deals?
segments.text_zh: 想知道超值优惠的秘诀吗？

segments.text_en: Shut up.
segments.text_zh: 住口。

segments.text_en: Recent research found that leaving a period of silence in negotiation, not only made it more likely that the other person would give you a high value move.
segments.text_zh: 最近的研究发现，在谈判中留下一段时间的沉默，不仅会让对方更有可能给你一个高价值的举动。

segments.text_en: But it also came across as collaborative.
segments.text_zh: 但它也给人一种协作的感觉。

segments.text_en: So, how much silence?
segments.text_zh: 那么，沉默到什么程度呢？

segments.text_en: I just did it three and a half seconds. See? You were nervous, but we all survived.
segments.text_zh: 我只用了三分半钟。看？你很紧张，但我们都活了下来。

segments.text_en: That's what I call landing the plane.
segments.text_zh: 这就是我所说的飞机着陆。

segments.text_en: Ask your question, make your proposal and then zip it.
segments.text_zh: 提出你的问题，提出你的建议，然后压缩它。

segments.text_en: And finally, lesson 5.
segments.text_zh: 最后是第 5 课。

segments.text_en: Make your adversary your partner.
segments.text_zh: 让你的对手成为你的伙伴。

segments.text_en: It's 3 a.m.
segments.text_zh: 现在是凌晨 3 点。

segments.text_en: And you have five hours to go before the entire world is expecting you and several other countries to announce a peace deal.
segments.text_zh: 距离全世界都期待你和其他几个国家宣布和平协议还有五个小时。

segments.text_en: But right now, you have a problem because one of the other countries diplomats has left the building and is down in the parking lot threatening to drive away because he feels disrespected.
segments.text_zh: 但现在，你遇到了一个问题，因为其他国家的一名外交官已经离开大楼，并在停车场威胁要开车离开，因为他感到不受尊重。

segments.text_en: This was the situation that one of the diplomats I work with faced.
segments.text_zh: 这就是与我共事的一位外交官所面临的情况。

segments.text_en: But a lot of us face things like this in our everyday negotiations.
segments.text_zh: But a lot of us face things like this in our everyday negotiations.

segments.text_en: So much of the popular wisdom talks about our adversary, our opponent.
segments.text_zh: So much of the popular wisdom talks about our adversary, our opponent.

segments.text_en: Well, in most everyday negotiations, that adversary at the bargaining table becomes our partner once that deal is done.
segments.text_zh: 嗯，在大多数日常谈判中，一旦交易完成，谈判桌上的对手就会成为我们的合作伙伴。

segments.text_en: The boss who holds the keys to your raise, once you get it, you're working together.
segments.text_zh: 老板掌握着你加薪的钥匙，一旦你得到加薪，你们就可以一起工作。

segments.text_en: Or that home contractor you're negotiating with over your kitchen.
segments.text_zh: 或者是你正在与厨房谈判的家庭承包商。

segments.text_en: Once you settle on a price, you're trusting her to build a room you're going to love for years to come.
segments.text_zh: Once you settle on a price, you're trusting her to build a room you're going to love for years to come.

segments.text_en: And even when your spouse might feel like an opponent, well, you're still sleeping in the same bed at the end of the day.
segments.text_zh: 即使你的配偶可能感觉自己是一个对手，好吧，一天结束时你们仍然睡在同一张床上。

segments.text_en: That diplomat I worked with, he walked out of the building down to the parking lot and he approached the man who had left.
segments.text_zh: 与我共事的那位外交官走出大楼，来到停车场，走近那位离开的人。

segments.text_en: He said to him, we are on the same side.
segments.text_zh: 他对他说，我们是同一边的。

segments.text_en: He listened.
segments.text_zh: 他听着。

segments.text_en: Eventually, the two men walked together back into that building and later they announced that peace deal.
segments.text_zh: 最终，两人一起走回那栋大楼，随后宣布了和平协议。

segments.text_en: My negotiation motto is this.
segments.text_zh: 我的谈判座右铭是这样的。

segments.text_en: I never request.
segments.text_zh: 我从不要求。

segments.text_en: I recruit.
segments.text_zh: 我招募。

segments.text_en: I don't want to talk to someone across the table.
segments.text_zh: 我不想和桌子对面的人说话。

segments.text_en: I want to pull them around with questions to my side of the table so that we are now co-penspirators working toward the same goal.
segments.text_zh: 我想把他们拉过来，向我这边提出问题，这样我们现在就成为为同一目标而努力的共同参与者。

segments.text_en: Negotiation is not about it.
segments.text_zh: 谈判不是这个问题。

segments.text_en: It is simply steering.
segments.text_zh: 这只是转向。

segments.text_en: And if we lead with curiosity about ourselves and about others, we won't just create great deals.
segments.text_zh: 如果我们以对自己和他人的好奇心来领导，我们将不仅仅创造伟大的交易。

segments.text_en: We'll create great relationships along the way.
segments.text_zh: 我们将一路建立良好的关系。

segments.text_en: Speaking of which, you might be wondering, what happened after the honeymoon?
segments.text_zh: 说到这里，你可能会想，蜜月之后发生了什么？

segments.text_en: Well, I'm glad to report that my husband and I have been happily steering together for 18 years.
segments.text_zh: 好吧，我很高兴地向大家报告，我和丈夫已经愉快地一起掌舵 18 年了。

segments.text_en: Just not in a kayak.
segments.text_zh: 只是不在皮艇里。

segments.text_en: Thank you.
segments.text_zh: 谢谢。

segments.text_en: You
segments.text_zh: 你
